0:
Japanese Buddhist architecture is the architecture of Buddhist temples in Japan, consisting of locally developed variants of architectural styles born in China.

<Triplets:<Japanese Buddhist architecture
1:
--------------------

Text: Japanese Buddhist architecture:  After Buddhism arrived the continent via Three Kingdoms of Korea in the 6th century, an effort was initially made to reproduce original buildings as faithfully as possible, but gradually local versions of continental styles were developed both to meet Japanese tastes and to solve problems posed by local weather, which is more rainy and humid than in China.

--------------------
Text: Japanese Buddhist architecture:  The first Buddhist sects were Nara's six Nanto Rokushū (南都六宗 , Nara six sects ) , followed during the Heian period by Kyoto's Shingon and Tendai.
